title: Elton John's brother slams star for demonising their dad in new autobiography
text:

Elton John’s half-brother has slammed the star for playing the “blame card” and unfairly demonising their dad.

Geoff Dwight spoke out after the pop veteran, 72, presented an unflattering picture of their family life in his new autobiography, Me.

Elton says he was “scared” of their dad Stanley Dwight, adding: “I don’t recall him ever coming to see me play live, or talking about music with him.

“What I was doing clearly wasn’t really his thing.”

But Geoff, 53, said: “I don’t understand because my mum, my dad and me, we all went to see him as his guests in Liverpool.

“That was definitely a concert, my dad was definitely there, he was definitely playing and we definitely watched it. I was five.

“Either he has got massive memory loss and he genuinely thinks his dad hasn’t seen him in concert or maybe he wants to believe that.”

(Image: John Gladwin/Sunday Mirror)

Carpenter Geoff reckons it is all part of his brother failing to accept responsibility for his life.

Stanley split with Elton’s mum Sheila in 1962 and went on to have four more children with second wife Edna. First child Stan, now an accountant, was followed by Robert, who works for the Lottery operator Camelot.

Geoff came next and finally Simon, who is now a civil engineer.

As the boys grew up, Elton became a glamorous uncle figure – but for large sections of his adult life, Elton rarely saw their father. And in the book, he recalls how Stanley snubbed his offer to help him when he was dying.

He writes: “My father had a heart problem and needed a quadruple bypass. I phoned and offered to pay for him to have the operation done privately. He flatly refused. It was a shame... but he didn’t want my help.”

(Image: Mirrorpix)

But Geoff hit back: “Dad was getting treated by the NHS and Elton offered him private treatment. But the NHS group knew my dad, they knew his conditions, what are you going to do? Just spend money on a private guy who he didn’t know?

“There are some things money can’t buy. There was no agenda or malice from my dad, he was like ‘Life isn’t just about me, there are other people involved as well’.”

Elton also claims his dad never told him he was proud of him. And Geoff admits Stanley never told him he loved him until he was about to die – but insists it was down to his tough post-war upbringing.

(Image: Getty Images for EJAF)

He said: “I had this terrible comedown after a night out. I was thinking about my dad and thinking ‘You weren’t there for that, you didn’t do that’. My mind found every way to destroy him. Then my mind eased up. I thought, ‘But then you have given me that strength.’

“We are responsible for ourselves. I could turn round to Elton and say ‘You’ve actually had it really good’. But if all you see is the negative, you are not seeing the positive.

“The anger he feels towards his father and mother, I could allow myself to be the same but I wouldn’t pin it on my parents. I would pin it on the culture out of which they came.

“He is playing the blame card. But our parents came from war, where men had to be men and women had to be women. It’s a different world.”

(Image: WireImage)

When Stanley was on his deathbed in 1991, it was Geoff and his brothers who nursed him. Geoff said: “My dad... I can remember him saying ‘I love you’ but it was on his deathbed. There were four of us brothers there – Elton wasn’t. When my dad was dying in hospital, he said, ‘Take me home, I don’t want to die here’.

“When I took him home, I said, ‘Dad, I love you’. And he said, ‘Yes, love is what it is all about’. That

generation just didn’t express emotion in the same way we do now.”

Elton’s book is also critical of mother Sheila, who died aged 92 in 2017. Elton – played by Taron Egerton in this year’s biopic Rocketman – claims she tried to ruin his 2014 wedding to David Furnish, ­writing: “One of Mum’s moods ­appeared to be upon us.”

(Image: Corbis via Getty Images)

Geoff said: “He has bottled this up. Maybe she was the one person he could never upstage. Elton has been critical of my dad for a while. But now his mum is not around, she can’t scare him into not saying anything.”

But Geoff believes fatherhood has been the making of Elton, who is

raising Elijah, six, and Zachary, eight, with David. He said: “I think he needs children in his life.”

And Geoff’s simple life is a far cry from Elton’s, based in a remote cottage that has a huge board of star signs on the wall while a Hindu trident sits on the ­window ledge.

He recalls a time his van broke down near Elton’s Windsor mansion – and he met David for the first and only time.

He said: “David came along in a Bentley and wound down his window. He smiled and said, ‘Jealous?’. He drove off. It’s the only time I met him. I wasn’t expecting that. It really shocked me.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Geoff, jailed at 18 over a botched burglary, says being Elton’s brother was difficult at times. “Elton is a rock star who happens to be related to me. It is inescapable. In prison, I was hit by this fella who knew I was Elton’s brother. He split my jaw.”

But despite everything, Geoff insists he is proud of Elton – who was born Reginald Dwight. “He is a Dwight boy, of course I am proud of him. He’s gone out and rocked it and fair play to him.

“My dad was proud of him, you could see when Elton popped up on TV, his eyes lit up.”

But as he gets ready to go foraging for mushrooms in the Welsh countryside, Geoff adds: “I don’t know if I’ll read the book. I’ve got a better read on now about Norwegian wood chopping.”

Elton’s spokesman said: “Elton stands by what he said in the book about his dad never seeing him perform. David has never spoken to or met Geoff, and the alleged incident did not happen.”

A rep for Elton said: “Elton stands by what he said in the book about his dad never seeing him perform as Elton John. David has never spoken to or met Geoff, and the alleged incident on the driveway did not happen.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: Our dad was proud of the Rocketman but just didn't now how to say 'I love you'
